journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Analysis of the compressive behaviour of the three-dimensional printed porous titanium for dental implants using a modified cellular solid model

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, The University of Sheffield, Sheffield, UK
2School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast, UK

author-notes.corresp: Elaheh Ghassemieh, School of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Queen’s University Belfast, Belfast BT9 5AH, UK. Email: e.ghassemieh@gmail.com

abstract.p: A set of cylindrical porous titanium test samples were produced using the three-dimensional printing and sintering method with samples sintered at 900 °C, 1000 °C, 1100 °C, 1200 °C or 1300 °C. Following compression testing, it was apparent that the stress–strain curves were similar in shape to the curves that represent cellular solids. This is despite a relative density twice as high as what is considered the threshold for defining a cellular solid. As final sintering temperature increased, the compressive behaviour developed from being elastic–brittle to elastic–plastic and while Young’s modulus remained fairly constant in the region of 1.5 GPa, there was a corresponding increase in 0.2% proof stress of approximately 40–80 MPa. The cellular solid model consists of two equations that predict Young’s modulus and yield or proof stress. By fitting to experimental data and consideration of porous morphology, appropriate changes to the geometry constants allow modification of the current models to predict with better accuracy the behaviour of porous materials with higher relative densities (lower porosity).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cellular solids are a class of material characterised by a porous or ‘cellular’ morphology with a relative density of 0.3 or less.1,2 In addition to encompassing a wide range of engineered materials, cellular solids are also widely found in nature.3 The materials prove useful as the cellular structure allows modification of the mechanical properties resulting in the ability to customise materials for a wider range of applications.4 Modification of the mechanical properties to effectively meet specifications has been enabled in no small part by the extensive work on cellular solids by Gibson and Ashby. Their work systematically covers a definition of cellular solids and the range of structures that can make up cellular morphologies, basic two-dimensional (2D) and advanced three-dimensional (3D) theoretical derivations of cellular solid properties and the resulting material behaviour.1,5–9 This has allowed the mechanical properties of cellular solids to be more easily predicted, leading to simplification of including the materials in the design process.

When considering porous metals, relative densities rarely go as low as 0.3, that is, a porosity of 70%. While there is a range of literature investigating porous metals, the mechanical properties are reported with little or no attempt to model the behaviour based on the results.10,11 While work by Wen et al.12 does apply the cellular solid model to porous titanium, there is no attempt made to modify it to better fit the data. Other modelling of properties is restricted to prediction of Young’s modulus using Nielsen’s relationship.13,14 The lack of modelling is probably due to a lack of a convenient generic model, such as the cellular solid model, that applies to higher relative density porous solids. However, our recent research suggests that the stress–strain curves of porous titanium samples with relative densities in the region of 0.6 (approximately 40% porosity) have a similar shape to that of the ideal cellular solid stress–strain curve.15 This has prompted further investigation into the modification of the cellular solid model equations for elastic and yield behaviour to produce equations that contain geometry constants modified by fitting of experimental, mechanical and morphological data. The resulting equations will better predict the behaviour of high relative density porous solids.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: The porous titanium samples are produced using the 3D printing and sintering method, using grade 1 commercially pure (CP) titanium and polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a space-holder/porogen, as described in previous work16 with samples having a final sintering temperature (FST) of 900 °C, 1000 °C, 1100 °C, 1200 °C or 1300 °C. The produced samples were roughly cylindrical with approximate dimensions of 10 mm length × 5 mm diameter (Figure 1(a)).

caption.p: (a) Images showing a complete test sample and (b) internal morphology from a micro-CT scan.

sec.title: Micro-computed tomography imaging
sec.p: Micro-computed tomography (micro-CT) imaging data gathered using established procedure17 and reported in previous work provided the required morphology data.

The scanner (1172; Skyscan, Kontich, Belgium) that has been used is a high-resolution, compact desktop unit with associated control, reconstruction (NRecon, Skyscan) and analysis (CTAn/CTVol, Skyscan) software. In order to image the denser titanium and capture the correct resolution, the energy of the scan is increased to the maximum 100 kV (∼100 µA), which results in approximately 20% X-ray penetration through the body of the sample. The ‘medium’ camera is used for image capture with a pixel size of 4.3 µm, standard settings of 590 ms capture time, 0.7° step size and three images per step for noise reduction averaging. An aluminium and copper (Al+Cu) filter ensures only X-rays of adequate strength are reaching the target.

Image processing settings are kept constant for the reconstruction of all images with the upper and lower bounds of the dynamic range set to 0.12 and 0, respectively. Volumes of interest (VOIs) are created in the reconstructed datasets from 1 mm × 1 mm square regions of interest and thresholded, with an upper bound of 200 and a lower bound of 60, to produce binary image data (Figure 1(b)). 3D analysis of the VOIs outputs comprehensive data on sample morphology – this includes overall porosity, open (interconnected) porosity, average pore size, pore size distribution, titanium strut size and strut size distribution. The micro-CT image analysis is used to obtain quantitative information regarding the morphology of the porous titanium samples. The morphological data are then used in our cellular to predict the elastic modulus. Some of the morphological data obtained by the micro-CT are reported in Table 1. This includes relative density obtained from porosity data, average pore diameter and wall thickness, which are all obtained by the analysis of the micro-CT images.

caption.p: Morphological parameters of samples with different FSTs obtained by image analysis of micro-CT images.

sec.title: Compression testing
sec.p: Force–displacement raw data is generated via compression testing carried out to the American Society for Metals (ASM) axial compression testing standard18 on a universal test rig (Hounsfield, Hounsfield now Tinius Olsen, Surrey, UK) with compressive load cell. The samples are loaded axially at a strain rate of 0.5 mm/min to approximately 75% strain or until the sample fails. The raw data are then used to calculate (engineering) stress–strain curves for each of the tested samples. The results of the test are shown in Figures 2–4 and is also used to obtain Young’s modulus E* and 0.2% proof stress σ0.2% in Table 2.

caption.p: Comparison of stress–strain curves across all FSTs.
Elastic and yield phase of the 1000 °C FST sample stress–strain curve.
Full stress–strain curve of the 1000 °C FST sample showing secondary failures.
Elastic modulus and yield stress of samples with different FSTs comparison of measurements and cellular model predictions.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: This investigation was instigated due to previous work12 indicating that porous titanium samples were displaying similar behaviour, under compressive load, to the compressive stress–strain curve of an ideal cellular solid.15 Namely, the stress–strain curve consists of an elastic region followed by brittle failure for elastic–brittle materials and an elastic region, plateau phase and densification phase for elastic–plastic materials (Figure 2). This is despite the material not strictly being a cellular solid – between 35% and 40%, the porosity is too low (relative density of 0.6–0.65). The cellular solid model sets the threshold of relative density at 0.3 due to the nature of cell geometries. Beyond this density, cell size (diameter) and cell wall thickness begin to approach similar values, and the beam bending theory used to model the deformation of cell walls is less applicable as the increasingly squat cell walls fail axially rather than through bending.19 However, the shape of the compressive stress–strain curves of the sample material suggests a modified model could be possible for higher relative densities.

With samples sintered at lower FSTs, elastic–brittle behaviour was observed. The lowest FST produced samples that failed following the elastic phase while increasing intermediate FSTs produced progressively less erratic plateau phases and increasing evidence of densification. The highest sintering temperature produced a stress–strain curve that best corresponds to elastic–plastic behaviour. This was supported by observations during the experiments with the samples that failed at the end of the elastic phase fracturing and crumbling away from below the cross head. The degree of fracturing was less pronounced with subsequent increasing FST samples and no observable incidence in the highest FST samples.

In order to provide a consistent measure of a yield point across the stress–strain curves of all samples, the 0.2% proof stress method will be used. To allow for the derivation of the 0.2% proof stress, it proved necessary to reassess the raw data and draw the elastic phase of the curves at better resolution using a finer sampling interval. This also involved adjusting the datapoints at the start of the curve to compensate for the small stresses at small strains related to the levelling of the compressive test rig cross head on a surface that may not have been perfectly flat and, therefore, not allowing a fully accurate representation of the elastic properties of the samples. The result of this adjustment of the raw data is a refinement of the values of sample Young’s moduli in addition to accurate estimations of when the material can be considered to have yielded (Table 2 and Figure 3). Analysis of variance (ANOVA) analysis on the data obtained from analysis of the compression tests for modulus and proof stress indicates statistically significant differences in the range of FSTs considered. However, it should be noted that these changes are not large. The main reason is that sintering stage is used to consolidate the titanium phase and removal of the PVA agent. In the range of the temperatures (900 °C–1300 °C), the consolidation and removal are achieved reasonably. The morphological changes are mainly directed by the size and shape of the PVA and the size of the titanium powder, which have been the same in all cases. Therefore, the differences in the morphology of samples such as pore shape, size, porosity and density have not been large (while statistically significant).

Other than the samples with an FST of 900 °C that underwent brittle failure following the elastic phase and can, therefore, be discounted, all samples display some sort of post-yield behaviour. Relating the plateau phase to observations of the samples during testing, it is apparent that the erratic nature is due to a series of ‘secondary failures’ (Figure 4). These are manifest as small pieces of the sample breaking away from the main body, accompanied by a corresponding drop in recorded stress. The lack of densification is due to the amount of secondary failures that occur – if the number is sufficient, there is not enough left of the sample for the test to continue. At higher FSTs, the plateau becomes more regular although there is still one or two instances of secondary failure with corresponding drops in stress. As the majority of the sample survives, there is sufficient material to allow densification to occur. Relating back to the cellular solid model, it is stated that densification begins at a relative density of approximately 0.5.19 As the tested samples have densities of approximately 0.6 to begin with, well above this threshold, densification is already occurring during the plateau phase. This is evident from the inclined nature of the post-yield plateau. The model’s assumption of axial failure at higher relative densities is also indicated by the nature of the secondary failures, which occur with parts breaking off the main sample along failure planes orientated at approximately 45° to the direction of applied load. This suggests, as expected, that a combination of beam bending of cell walls and axial failure is active following the elastic phase, and that the titanium colonies that make up the cell walls at higher FSTs are possibly less inclined towards axial failure, indicated by the reduction in the secondary failures.

The transition from plateau phase densification to full densification phase is indicated by a large increase in the gradient of the graph in the region of 70% strain. As relative densities are similar regardless of FST, all samples that show evidence of densification do so at approximately the same strain level, indicating the relationship between relative density and final densification.

sec.title: Elastic phase model
sec.p: Fitting of the recorded data to the model is based on equations derived from the geometry of cellular solid morphology

where E* is the modulus of the porous material, Es is the modulus of the solid, t is the pore wall thickness, l is the strut (pore wall) length, C1 is a geometry factor, ρ* is the density of the porous material and ρs is the density of the solid.19 For the purpose of this investigation, a value of 110 GPa is used as Young’s modulus of grade 1 CP titanium. Using the cellular solid model, where C1 = 1, over-predicts the value of Young’s modulus by a considerable margin at the relative densities being investigated. It should be noted that in the work by Wen et al.,12 which produced porous titanium by a powder metallurgy-porogen method, the unmodified cellular solid model also over-predicted the values of Young’s modulus across a range of relative densities in excess of the 0.3 threshold. Therefore, modification of the model to fit the recorded data may be achieved by applying a more appropriate value of C1.

From equation (1), it is clear that as the slenderness of the pore walls (ratio of strut length to thickness) decreases, so does the porous modulus. Equation (2) shows that a decrease in relative density will also result in a reduction in the porous modulus. In basic terms, if a standard pore shape is assumed, it is possible to envisage relative density decreasing due to an increase in pore size, an increase in the number of pores with their size remaining constant, a larger increase in the number of pores while their size reduces or a combination of these effects. However, a decrease in relative density combined with a decrease in slenderness would only occur in the case of an increase in pore numbers with a reduction in pore size. Therefore, it is necessary to consider the shape of the pores, enabled by the inclusion of the geometry factor term in equation (2). The morphological analysis outputs data on pore size as an average diameter, equating pores to a sphere. If this dimension is considered for a variety of shapes to derive strut lengths, which represent various values of the geometry factor, it is possible to see how much pore shape influences the modulus of the porous material. Slenderness is related to relative density and pore shape by19
which means a value for the geometry factor can be calculated from

The relative density (porosity) and wall thickness values are output from the morphological analysis. Variation in strut length occurs by considering pores with varying cross-sectional shapes and relating these to the pore diameters (d) output by the morphological analysis. Pore cross section can be assumed to vary from square to decagonal as they become more spherical (Table 3 and Figure 5(a)). The graph indicates that the value of C1 that best results in predicted moduli matching measured moduli is derived from a strut length relating to an octagonal cross section (Figure 5(b)). This again corresponds well with the model for a true cellular solid. Rather than being spherical, the cells (or pores) of true cellular solids are commonly tetrakaidecahedra6– a 14-faced 3D shape that an 8-sided cross section is a good fit for. The results of the estimated elastic modulus using the octagonal
E
oc
*
and decagonal geometries
E
dc
*
are reported in Table 2. The results of modulus estimation using various shape cells in cellular model are presented in Figure 5 alongside with the modulus values obtained from compression tests. The comparison shows that an octagonal shape offers closest match to the experimental results. It should be noted that the cellular model assumes that the cellular structure is uniform, indicating a repeating units through the microstructure. It also assumes that the pore has regular shape, wall thickness and pore size. All these assumptions are far from the real morphology of the porous structure, which has range of pore sizes and shapes and wall thicknesses. These assumptions are the causes of the discrepancies between the model and measured results.

caption.p: Strut length for various cell geometries.

(a) Circular pore cross-sectional estimations using other shapes and resulting edge lengths and (b) comparison of the various cross-sectional cellular solid model predictions and measured values of Young’s modulus.
The octagonal shape presented the best fit.

sec.title: Yield model
sec.p: In a similar way to how the modulus is modelled during the elastic phase, modelling of a yield point is also based on equations derived from the cellular solid morphology

where σys is the yield strength (or in this case, the 0.2% proof stress) of the solid material and C5 is the geometry factor.19 Taking a value of 220 MPa as the 0.2% proof stress of grade 1 CP titanium and a guideline value of C5 = 0.3, as used in the standard cellular solid model, the predicted and measured values of
σ
pl
*
can be compared. It can be seen (Table 2 and Figure 6) that this value of C5 under-predicts the recorded values by a large margin. Again, a similar thing is seen in the work by Wen et al.12 with the cellular solid model under-predicting yield stress levels. With increased relative densities, such as that of the tested samples, an increase in the value of C5 is needed to bring the model values in-line with the measured values. As the original model is based on a relative density of 0.3 and a C5 value of 0.3, modelling with C5 equal to the relative density was used to produce modified model values. This modified model much more closely approximates the data recorded experimentally. The results of the standard model and modified model predictions and values obtained from the stress strain curves of the compressive tests for σ0.2% are reported in Table 2.

caption.p: Comparison of the cellular solid model, modified model and measured values of 0.2% proof stress.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: By making use of the equations that constitute the cellular solid model, it is proved possible to extend the model from true cellular solids to cover porous materials with relative densities in excess of 0.3. Image analysis techniques are developed to obtain information related to the morphology of the porous titanium using micro-CT imaging. Applying specific outputs from morphological analysis of porous material, the cellular model equations for predicting modulus can be modified to represent the experimental data. It is important to assess the cell geometry that brings the best fit between the cellular model and the test data in the analysis of Young’s modulus of the porous titanium.

Fairly accurate prediction of yield values is also possible by modifying the coefficient in the yield equation to a value represented by the relative density. Since the input of the cellular model is fairly dependent on the cell geometry and morphological information fed to the model, the initial assessment of the morphology plays an important role in the accuracy of the model predictions.
